input.code:
## Introduction

This short Scala crash course is based on [Scala School by Twitter](https://twitter.github.io/scala_school/).

We chose Scala as the language for the course (as well as the language we develop our systems in) because of several reasons, some of which are:

* Increasingly used in NLP and ML, but don't take our word for it, take a look at the code of some of the world's leading labs: [UCL Machine Reading group](https://github.com/uclmr/) :), [Berkeley NLP Group](http://nlp.cs.berkeley.edu/) and [another interesting ML project at UC Berkeley](http://bid2.berkeley.edu/bid-data-project/) , [University of Washington](http://knowitall.github.io/openie/), [Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence](https://github.com/allenai), etc.
* Expressive - Scala offers first class functions, and closures, and effectively enables you to quickly rewrite pseudocode or math models to code
* Concise - it offers type inference, and is on the quest to eliminate boilerplate code
* Java interoperability - you can reuse your favorite Java libraries! This comes in VERY handy.
* bear in mind that Scala is not Java on steroids :) it is just a different, object-oriented functional programming language (cannot stress the functional part enough)

## Installing scala
In order to install Scala, please follow [these instructions](http://www.scala-lang.org/download/install.html).

Starting the interpreter

Programming in IntelliJ

## Scala basics

This part of the book concerns the basics of Scala, a quick crash-course of Scala which you will need in order to understand this book, and be able to code up your assignments. All sorts of feedback are welcome and highly appreciated!

You can run these commands either in IntelliJ, or by running

`sbt console`

or

`scala`

in your command line, and thus entering Scala's REPL (Read-Evaluate-Print Loop) interpreter.

### Expressions

Almost everything in Scala is an expression, for example:

numerical calulations...

// Scala's interpretes automatically resolves the type of the expression in most cases
1.5 + 1.21828189

// see the difference between calling infix operators, and calling them as methods
"Soft" + " " + "kitty," + " warm".+(" kitty")

extraFields.aggregatedCells: ["// Scala's interpretes automatically resolves the type of the expression in most cases\n1.5 + 1.21828189"]

input.code:
// a convenient way to code piecewise functions
if (2 > 5 || 5 > 2) 7 else 4

extraFields.aggregatedCells: ["// Scala's interpretes automatically resolves the type of the expression in most cases\n1.5 + 1.21828189","// see the difference between calling infix operators, and calling them as methods\n\"Soft\" + \" \" + \"kitty,\" + \" warm\".+(\" kitty\")"]

input.code:
### Values and variables

Scala suports values and variables. Values are technically constants, and they cannot be changed (they are immutable), as opposed to variables which can (are mutable). Try removing the commented piece of code to verify that:

extraFields.aggregatedCells: ["// Scala's interpretes automatically resolves the type of the expression in most cases\n1.5 + 1.21828189","// see the difference between calling infix operators, and calling them as methods\n\"Soft\" + \" \" + \"kitty,\" + \" warm\".+(\" kitty\")","if (2 > 5 || 5 > 2) 7 else 4 "]

input.code:
var variable = "However, I can!"
variable = "See? I can change!"
variable

extraFields.aggregatedCells:
["// Scala's interpretes automatically resolves the type of the expression in most cases
1.5 + 1.21828189","// see the difference between calling infix operators, and calling them as methods
"Soft" + " " + "kitty," + " warm".+(" kitty")","if (2 > 5 || 5 > 2) 7 else 4 ","val value = "I cannot be changed! Really!"
// value = "But surely, this is not true?!"
value"]

input.code:
You might ask yourself: why should I use values and immutable structure? There are several reasons for and against using them. Immutable structures help with reasoning about the code, concurrency, make the code less prone to bugs (no references to take care of), etc. You can find a couple of thoughts abot that [here](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/214714/mutable-vs-immutable-objects) and [here](http://programmers.stackexchange.com/questions/151733/if-immutable-objects-are-good-why-do-people-keep-creating-mutable-objects).
You might also ask yourself: how do I change something in an immutable structure then? Easily - you copy it with a change in place :)
However, you will see more in the rest of the tutorial.

### Functions

In Scala, functions are objects you create with the keyword `def`, e.g.:

def sum(a: Int, b: Int): Int = a + b
sum(9000, 1)

extraFields.aggregatedCells:

1.5 + 1.21828189","// see the difference between calling infix operators, and calling them as methods
"Soft" + " " + "kitty," + " warm".+(" kitty")","if (2 > 5 || 5 > 2) 7 else 4 ","val value = "I cannot be changed! Really!"
// value = "But surely, this is not true?!"
value","var variable = "However, I can!"
variable = "See? I can change!"
variable"]

input.code:
As you can see from the definition, you need to specify the type of the parameters, but you can freely omit the output type as the interpreter/compiler will do that implicitly (except in cases of recursive functions).
Functions can be stored in variables and passed as parameters, as they are full-fledged Scala objects.

Let's take a look at a couple of functions' capabilities on a small NLP example - let's build something (maybe) useful which depluralizes (removes suffixes of plural forms of) nouns:

// value = "But surely, this is not true?!"
value","var variable = "However, I can!"
variable = "See? I can change!"
variable","def sum(a: Int, b: Int): Int = a + b"]

input.code:
### More on functions

Scala enables you to use a couple of other very useful constructs, like:

anonymous functions, or unnamed functions:

extraFields.aggregatedCells:
["// Scala's interpretes automatically resolves the type of the expression in most cases
1.5 + 1.21828189","// see the difference between calling infix operators, and calling them as methods
"Soft" + " " + "kitty," + " warm".+(" kitty")","if (2 > 5 || 5 > 2) 7 else 4 ","val value = "I cannot be changed! Really!"
// value = "But surely, this is not true?!"
value","var variable = "However, I can!"
variable = "See? I can change!"
variable","def sum(a: Int, b: Int): Int = a + b","// defining a function which works with a single String parameter
def depluralizer(word: String) =
   if (word.takeRight(4) == "sses" || word.takeRight(3) == "ies" )
        word.stripSuffix("es")
   else if (word.takeRight(2) == "ss")
     word
   else
     word.stripSuffix("s")

def exclamator(word: String) = word + "!"

depluralizer("businesses")"]

input.code: partially applied functions, which fix a subset of the input domain:

// partial function application
def addSuffix(stem: String, suffix: String): String = stem + suffix

val addIng = addSuffix(_:String, "ing")

addIng("Learn")

kitty("warm")

### Pattern Matching

Pattern matching is the [second most](http://www.tutorialspoint.com/scala/scala_pattern_matching.htm) used feature of scala. It is a general pattern matching mechanism which allows you to match on any kind of data.

Let's take a look at a small example:

   if (word.takeRight(4) == "sses" || word.takeRight(3) == "ies" )
        word.stripSuffix("es")
   else if (word.takeRight(2) == "ss")
     word
   else
     word.stripSuffix("s")

def exclamator(word: String) = word + "!"

depluralizer("businesses")","// save an anonymous function into a value

    args.foldLeft("")((x: String, y: String) => x + delimiter + y)
}
concatenateAll("+","soft", "kitty", "warm", "kitty")"]

input.code:
We can use the pattern matching syntax to create full-functions, piecewise functions, and partial functions.

For example, you can define a factorial function with pattern matching like so
We can also use pattern matching to check for types of arguments like so:

### Pattern matching with Case classes

Case classes are regular Scala classes wtich export their constructor parameters and enable you to recursively decompose them with pattern matching.

For example, let's build a small tree-like structure in Scala with case classes, and build a specific instance of a tree:

abstract class Node
case class Split(left: Node, right: Node) extends Node
case class Leaf(value: Int) extends Node

val tree = Split(Leaf(2),Split(Leaf(1),Leaf(10)))

Note how we did not need to construct a clase class element with the keyword `new`.

Now we can recursively decompose our tree and match on its contents in order to traverse it and apply a specific function on it, for example, let's return a sum of all the elements in a tree.
Exercise: upgrade this structure and the function to evaluate simple mathematical expressions with addition, subtraction, multiplication and division.

Collections in scala is a set of useful classes and interfaces which enable you efficient data storage and processing. They are divided in mutable and immutable structures (check more about this [here](http://docs.scala-lang.org/overviews/collections/overview.html)).

Before going further, just a word on preformance: know your data structures! Whatever you are using, if you are concerned with performance, [documentation](http://docs.scala-lang.org/overviews/collections/performance-characteristics.html) is your best friend!

### Lists

Lists are simple [linked lists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked_list) ([#ScalaDoc](http://www.scala-lang.org/api/current/index.html#scala.collection.immutable.List)), coming in an immutable and mutable flavor.

Let's take a look at a small example:
List tail (list after the first element)
Prepending an element (adding an element to the beginning of the list):

val tokens2 = List("Jack", "!", "What", "...", "are", "you", "?")
tokens2
val tokens3 = tokens1 ++ tokens2
tokens3
Getting unique elements from a list:

### Sets

Sets are data structures which store elements without an order and repetition.

An example:

val words1 = Set("Do", ",", "or", "do", "not", ".",
                 "There", "is", "no", "try", ".")
words1

val words2 = Set("A", "martini", ".",
                 "Shaken", ",", "not", "stirred", ".")

### Maps

A map (associative array, dictionary) is a data structure is a collection of key-value pairs, such that key appears only once.
Fetching an element of the map corresponding to the key tokens:

### Tuples

Tuples are fixed-length lists, in Scala denoted in a specific format:
You can access specific elements of that list by using the following notation:

val lemmaOpt1 = lemmas.get("tokens")
lemmaOpt1
lemmaOpt1.get

val lemmaOpt2 = lemmas.get("Open the pod bay doors, HAL.")
lemmaOpt2

if (lemmaOpt2.isDefined)
  lemmaOpt2.get
else
  "I'm sorry, Dave."
  
lemmaOpt2.getOrElse("I'm afraid I can't do that.").toString

tokens1

var counts = 0
tokens1.foreach(t => t.toCharArray.foreach(c => counts += 1))
counts

def sigmoid(: Double) = 1 / (1 + math.exp(-))
sigmoid(3)

def plusOne(i: Double) = i + 1
val fun1 = sigmoid _ compose plusOne
fun1(2) //sigmoid(plusOne(2))

  (arg, value) match {
 case ("-x", x) => "-x" + x
 case ("-v", v: Int) if (v<3) => "-v < 3"
 case ("-v", weird_value) => "-v weird value!!"
 case unk => "An unknown argument: " + unk
}

case class Split(left: Node, right: Node) extends Node
case class Leaf(value: Int) extends Node
val tree = Split(Leaf(2),Split(Leaf(1),Leaf(10)))

def sum(tree: Node): Int = tree match {
 case Leaf(n) => n
 case Split(left, right) => sum(left) + sum(right)
}

input.code:
case class Sentence(tokens: Seq[String])
case class Document(sentences: Seq[Sentence])

val docs = Seq(
    Document(Seq(Sentence(Seq("I", "like", "Scala", ".")))),
    Document(Seq(Sentence(Seq("Really", "?")),
                 Sentence(Seq("I", "like", "NLP", ".")))))

var shortTokens = 0
for (doc <- docs)
  for (sentence <- doc.sentences)
    for (token <- sentence.tokens)
      if (token.length < 3) shortTokens += 1
shortTokens
